title: 104_hr4262
content:
The "Child Passenger Protection Act" may be cited as the short title. The findings of the Act are also included. The Congress finds that annually in the United States, motor vehicle collisions result in over 800 deaths and 80,000 injuries to children under 4 years old. Properly used child restraints can significantly reduce the risk of serious or fatal injuries in these collisions. However, common seating designs in vehicles make secure installation of child restraints challenging, leading to a high percentage of improperly installed or misused restraints. There is a need to expand child restraint education programs to address the challenges of installing and misusing child restraints due to the complexity of seat belt and restraint designs. Child passenger education programs are being expanded to address challenges with installing and misusing child restraints. The Secretary may provide funding to State highway offices and child passenger safety organizations for child restraint education programs aimed at preventing injuries to children up to age 4. Programs include educating the public on proper installation of child restraints and selecting appropriate designs. The funding provided by the Secretary supports child restraint education programs for children up to age 4. This includes educating on proper installation and design selection, harness threading, and adjustment. Professionals and educators are trained in all aspects of child restraint use. Funds must be distributed with 25% for nationwide programs, 25% for state programs, and at least 50% for new national, state, and local programs. SEC. 4. APPLICATIONS AND REPORTS. Entities seeking funding must submit an application to the Secretary, including necessary information. Recipients of funding must submit annual reports detailing program activities, such as child restraint education programs and support materials developed. Entities seeking funding must submit an application to the Secretary, including necessary information. Recipients of funding must submit annual reports detailing program activities, support materials obtained, distribution methods, and initiatives for public-private partnerships to secure non-Federal support for child restraint education programs. The Secretary will provide an annual report to Congress on the implementation of the Act, detailing programs and materials developed by funded entities. $7,500,000 is authorized for fiscal years 1998 and 1999 for section 3, with a limit of $350,000 for administrative costs. Definitions are provided in section 7. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS.

The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Transportation. Child restraint education programs include various educational materials. The term "State" encompasses all states and territories of the United States.
